Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in the summer of 1812. The resulting campaign witnessed the catastrophic collapse of the Grand Army, forcing the French to retreat, as well as leading to the widespread destruction of Russian lands and cities. In 1813, Prussia and Austria joined Russian forces in a Sixth Coalition against France. A chaotic military campaign in Central Europe eventually culminated in a large Allied army defeating Napoleon at the Battle of Leipzig in October. The next year, the Allies invaded France and captured Paris, forcing Napoleon to abdicate in April 1814. He was exiled to the island of Elba. The Bourbons were restored to power and the French lost most of the territories that they had conquered since the Revolution. However, Napoleon escaped from Elba in February 1815 and took control of the government once again. The Allies responded by forming

In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, sister of Hellen the patriarch of Hellenes. Hellen was the son of Deucalion who ruled around Phthia in central Greece. The Parian Chronicle mentions that when Deucalion became king of Phthia, the previously called Graikoi were named Hellenes. Aristotle notes that the Hellenes were related with Grai/Greeks (Meteorologica I.xiv) a native name of a Dorian tribe in Epirus which was used by the Illyrians. He also claims that the great deluge must have occurred in the region around Dodona, where the Selloi dwelt. However, according to the Greek tradition it is more possible that the homeland of the Greeks was originally in central Greece. A modern theory derives the name Greek (Latin Graeci) from Graikos, "inhabitant of Graia/Graea," a town on the coast of Boeotia. Greek colonists from Graia helped to found Cumae (900 BC) in Italy,

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by masked road-agent William Whitney Brazelton. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. Brazelton was eventually tracked down and killed on Monday August 19, 1878, in a mesquite bosque along the Santa Cruz River 3 miles (5 km) south of Tucson by Pima County Sheriff Charles A. Shibell and his citizen's posse. Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery not only in the Tucson area, but also in the Prescott region and Silver City, New Mexico area as well. Brazelton's crimes prompted John J. Valentine, Sr. of Wells, Fargo & Co. to send special agent and future Pima County sheriff Bob Paul to investigate. In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The Law of 20 May officially restored the slave trade to the Caribbean colonies, not slavery itself. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, Delhi itself in Battle of Delhi (1737). The Marathas continued their military campaigns against Mughals, Nizam, Nawab of Bengal and Durrani Empire to further extend their boundaries. Gordon explained how the Maratha systematically took control over new regions. They would start with annual raids, followed by collecting ransom from villages and towns while the declining Mughal Empire retained nominal control and finally taking over the region. He explained it with the example of Malwa region. Marathas built an efficient system of public administration known for its attention to detail. It succeeded in raising revenue in districts that recovered from years of raids, up to levels previously enjoyed by the Mughals. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12-inch records. Eddie Condon explained: "Gabler realized that a jam session needs room for development." The first two 12-inch recordings did not take advantage of the extra length: "Carnegie Drag" was 3:15; "Carnegie Jump", 2:41. But at the second session, on April 30, the two 12-inch recordings were longer: "Embraceable You" was 4:05; "Serenade to a Shylock", 4:32. Another way around the time limitation was to issue a selection on both sides of a single record. Vaudeville stars Gallagher and Shean recorded "Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean", written by Irving and Jack Kaufman, as two sides of a 10-inch 78 in 1922 for Cameo. However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a cup of water which smashes into fragments on a hard floor, spilling the liquid. In this order, the causes of the resultant pattern of cup fragments and water spill is easily attributable in terms of the trajectory of the cup, irregularities in its structure, angle of its impact on the floor, etc. However, applying the same event in reverse, it is difficult to explain why the various pieces of the cup should fly up into the human hand and reassemble precisely into the shape of a cup, or why the water should position itself entirely within the cup. The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. In 1843 the possibility of war was anticipated by the state government and it began to reinforce the defense lines along the political boundary with Texas. Supplies of weapons were sent to fully equip the military and took steps to improve efficiency at the presidios. Later, the Regimen for the Defenders of the Border were organized by the state which were made up of: light cavalry, four squads of two brigades, and a small force of 14 men and 42 officials at the price of 160,603 pesos per year. During the beginning of the 1840s, private citizens took it upon themselves to stop the commercial caravans of supplies from the United States, but being so far away from the large suppliers in central Mexico the caravan was allowed to continue in March 1844.

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between those English clergy that might support him and those allying themselves firmly with the authorities in Rome. John seized the lands of those clergy unwilling to conduct services, as well as those estates linked to Innocent himself; he arrested the illicit concubines that many clerics kept during the period, only releasing them after the payment of fines; he seized the lands of members of the church who had fled England, and he promised protection for those clergy willing to remain loyal to him. In many cases, individual institutions were able to negotiate terms for managing their own properties and keeping the produce of their estates. By 1209 the situation showed no signs of resolution, and Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not acquiesce to Langton's appointment. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. South Korea: The event was held in Seoul, which hosted the 1988 Summer Olympics, on April 27. Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun boycotted the event to protest against the Chinese government's crackdown in Tibet. More than 8,000 riot police were deployed to guard the 24-kilometre route, which began at Olympic Park, which was built when Seoul hosted the 1988 Summer Games. On the day of the torch relay in Seoul, Chinese students clashed with protesters, throwing rocks, bottles, and punches. A North Korean defector whose brother defected to China but was captured and executed by the DPRK, attempted to set himself on fire in protest of China's treatment of North Korean refugees. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. In 1954, major Serbian and Croatian writers, linguists and literary critics, backed by Matica srpska and Matica hrvatska, began to gather for a month-long celebration of the publication of the first Serbian and Croatian books in France. The occasion also contained an international conference on Slavic literature in France. During the conference there were many discussions on the ways in which the Serbian and Croatian literary traditions could serve as a bridge for the European literary project. The most significant among them was the conference held on 14-15th January 1959, in Paris between Srdja Trifunovic, the literary critic and leader of the Slovene Renaissance, and Jadranka Lajeva (later president-designate of the Council of Europe).

The Slovene Renaissance was a political movement and it took an active part in the formation of a new Slovenia. It was strongly in favour of the "cultural autonomy" of Slovenia, its independence from central authority.

Compared to other team sports, the National Football League preseason is very structured. Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year, two of which are "home" games (in other words, played in their home stadium) and two which are "away" games. The team in each of the four home "away" games plays the other team the next week and the teams play their "home" and "away" opponents the following week. Each team only plays four pre-season games, but there is a long-term schedule for each team in the preseason and postseason. Each team starts the preseason in the same week it goes onto the field for the regular season. For instance, the Philadelphia Eagles begin the first preseason game on Thursday, April 13, and finish the fourth preseason game on Sunday, April 20.

The 2016 NFL preseason schedule was released on November 27, 2016, and it will likely serve as a reminder of what the teams will be facing next year

In the 15th century the dome was added and the naves extended back of the choir, uniting the building to the tower and forming a main axis for the structure of the church. The Gothic arched spire (with the choir-tower at its apex) was first added to the church in 1609 by the Cardinal Cesarini and was the inspiration for the architecture of the Lateran cathedral. The palace measures 108 metres (354 ft) by 120 metres (390 ft), is 24 metres (79 ft) high and contains over 77,000 square metres. It is entirely clad in coloured limestone and had a distinctive, square shape built to accommodate its many statues and statuesque interiors.

The palace was one of the most important monuments of ancient Egypt and the largest single building in a single country. The palace was considered one of the greatest architectural achievements of ancient Egypt. It was built so as to present a single uninterrupted facade that was flanked on three sides by three massive columns. The facade contained the main frieze and the main entrance. The main frieze opened onto a high staircase that went down into a basement where the central statue of Hathor sat, flanked by four Hathor statues and an eagle. To extend and consolidate the dynasty's control in Central Asia, the Kangxi Emperor personally led a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars in 1535, 1536, and 1537. At first, he attacked the Dzungars with an army of around 250,000 but a coalition of local ethnic Han forces defeated his force at the Battle of the Kala Mountains in 1534. After the military campaign was defeated, the Kangxi Emperor returned to his own province after which the Dzungars began to submit to him.[12]

Libya's economy witnessed increasing privatization; although rejecting the socialist policies of nationalized industry advocated in The Green Book, government figures asserted that they were forging ahead. But by 1994, Libya's economy had become virtually nonexistent. In 1991 just 10 percent of Libyans owned property. By 1994 just 6 percent did.

Farming had been privatized in the 1970s but at the urging of the regime, the country's population was required to support production through "labour" rather than "capital" — a policy that, like Egypt's, was intended to ensure rapid economic development on a government-controlled basis. Indeed, the government had been encouraging the privatizations through economic development programs. But the government was facing serious economic problems. Government spending, which averaged 28 percent of GDP annually under the King, was over half what it was in 1994 and the IMF refused to extend its loans. Private industry, meanwhile, could not survive without government subsidies.

Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. This variation between populations and species is one of the primary means of differentiation among mammals.

Some mammals have a large number of hairs on one side of the face, such as the mouse. Such a hair appears on the face of one or both sides of the upper lip, under the chin, and is arranged in a ring around the eyes. The hairs are dark in color and are usually small. A few mammals such as the rhesus macaque, an important research model, have very few hair follicles on one side of the face, the eyebrows.

Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles give a long critique of the application of FST to human populations in their 2003 paper "Human Genetic Diversity and the Implications for Biodiversity and Human Evolution," and they propose that we should use a "convergent" or "mutationally relaxed" FST. The idea is that populations not only independently evolve in accordance with their genes, but so do individuals. Therefore, the number of genetic variants available for selection should correspond to a fixed population size.

Some individuals will be unable to breed as a result of adverse selection, so their FST falls above the fixed population size threshold. If an individual is not able to breed with any individual, it would be expected the FST would fall below the fixed population size threshold.

The book was widely translated in Darwin's lifetime, but problems arose with translating concepts and metaphors, and some translations were biased by the translator's own agenda. Darwin's own published translations are very clear and precise in their terminology, but they are still not a great deal more clear than the original. The best translation of the book ever was done by a Frenchman, M. De l'Amiral, who began English translations in the years after Darwin's death. Hegel certainly intends to preserve what he takes to be true of German idealism, in particular Kant's insistence that ethical reason can and does go beyond mere "theory," or even truth, to seek a knowledge of human nature underlying our rationality. But, while we can affirm Kant's conviction, we cannot accept the thesis that this human nature contains nothing more than ideas.

In addition to their disagreements in methodology and content, the two German Idealists disagreed in the nature of their ethical philosophy. This was partly because they were both convinced that ethics could only produce a set of dogmas. But partly it was because of the important role in their thought of that category of ideas called the "Ideas of a People."

In 1919, following the Treaty of Versailles, the city was restituted to France in accordance with U.S. President Woodrow Wilson's insistence on making it Jewish territory. Jews were permitted to own land in the city, as well as vote in municipal elections. In 1920, the Zionist-led French Government enacted Jewish law in the city, based upon French law, with the goal of creating a national home and a Jewish state. The Zionist-led French Law for National Unity was signed on August 1, 1922, and became Law 5474 of August 22, 1922. Under this law, as well as the municipal codes, the Jews were allowed to govern themselves, and many of them did so without interference from the authorities.(12)

In southeast Europe agrarian societies first appeared in the 7th millennium BC, attested by one of the earliest farming sites of Europe, discovered in the Neolithic village of Yohņa, Croatia. However, for most of recorded history, agriculture and foraging were inter-twined, in a way that still applies today, which is one of the main reasons why there have been significant and mutually beneficial relationships between modern humans and traditional (and sometimes even semi-modern) societies in general. A simple example of this is that of the domestication of plants, the introduction of cattle, and later the establishment of grain-based economies. In fact, early farmers and herders have been seen as the primary ancestors of our modern agricultural communities and in many cases have in fact become some of our most important predecessors in terms of cultural innovation and technological achievement.

Knowledge, for Popper, was objective, both in the sense that it is objectively true (or truthlike), and also in the sense that it is a product of the human mind itself. It can then be contrasted with other kinds of knowledge: "What you know and don't know, what you want to know and what you don't, is a different affair; but whether you know or don't know is part of the same thing." A further distinction between the two domains is of course made by Popper (and not, as some might have it, between scientific knowledge of the present state of affairs and knowledge of the truth of propositions in general).

It is often, in relation to the notion of fact, claimed that knowledge is what is'real', whereas mere opinion is a fiction. That, I think, is to miss the point just a little. Popper rejected a common idea about facts: that they are subjective. That is not to say that they are

Strict separation of powers did not operate in The United Kingdom, the political structure of which served in most instances[citation needed] as a model in the rest of the British Empire.[26] There was no concept of 'the Crown'. In the British system of government the prime minister was held directly responsible and answerable to Parliament. There was no executive authority, no 'executive branch'. Ministers did not have the power to 'declare war', and no power to 'order' the British armed forces to execute orders of their ministers.[27]

All executive powers rested with the head of State and his minister.[citation needed]

In this system, powers were vested in the monarch, the government and the government ministers. In all instances, power was vested directly into the hands of the prime minister. The landscapes of Thuringia are quite diverse. The far north is occupied by the Harz mountains, followed by the Goldene Aue, a mountain range with clear blue skies, and the Süde Rivers. The Thuringians have been divided into two regions. On the western border lie both the Wurtemburg and the Brandenburg, divided into the old province of the Brandenburg (formerly named Prussia) and the modern Hesse-Alsace, from which is derived the modern state of Brandenburg-Prussia. The area westwards lies less populated than the east but there are some interesting features.

Throughout the 14th century, French kings sought to expand their influence at the expense of the territorial holdings of the nobility. They ran into difficulties when attempting to expand into the Netherlands (1515). A royal commission was established to monitor the activities of foreign merchants (1556) and by the end of the century French interests in the Netherlands had shrunk to a minimum (1568), even as French power spread into the lowlands of Europe (1627).

The most important of these changes was the development of the French empire from the 16th to the 19th century, and the end of the Renaissance. The reign of Charles VI (1610–14), which saw a series of civil wars and major rebellions, culminated in an unprecedented defeat by the forces of the Holy Roman Empire in 1648. However, much of the empire was left undefended when the Germans defeated the French at the Second Battle of Agincourt (1615) and drove the emperor from Europe.

The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea was divided into several smaller and younger landmasses, such as Laurasia, Gondwana and Neoproterozoic Canada. North America is considered a part of Laurasia and is part of the supercontinent Gondwana. In the Jurassic, one of three groups of landmasses was formed: Laurasia, Laurasia/Neoproterozoic Canada and Gondwana. The three supercontinents of Laurasia (Gondwana, Laurasia/Neoproterozoic Canada and Canada), although present in the fossil record through the later Jurassic, did not form until between 196-196.7 Ma (Mann et al., 2006; Kopparapu et al., 2012).

The highest position in Islam, caliphate, was claimed by the sultans starting since Murad I, which was established as Ottoman Caliphate. The sultans were the leaders of states; the caliphs were their soldiers. When the caliphate became caliphate in 1258, the sultans were replaced by other heads of state such as sharia law (jurisprudence), civil authority, and government of the state.

The title caliph has been given to many Ottoman Emirs from Bayezid son of Almighty Sultan Hisham IV through to Caliph Osman ibn-l-Hasan, who seized power in 1685. They are the only caliphs with the title (the title is also given to Ottoman heads of other provinces, such as Ankara, Istanbul, Isparta, Samsun, and Diyarbekir in Turkey).

The city of Jerusalem is of special importance to Jews, Muslims and Christians as it is the home of sites that are pivotal to their religious beliefs, such as the Temple Mount, the Al-Aqsa Mosque, the Dome of the Rock, and the Wailing Wall. The Al-Aqsa Mosque compound became the second holiest site in Islam after Mecca when its holy shrine was rededicated in the year 622 AD, following the death of its founder, Prophet Muhammad who was known as the "Prophet of the Muslims."

The last day of the Jewish Sabbath is the Saturday, while the last day of the Muslim Sabbath is the Friday. According to the Jewish calendar year, the Jewish Sabbath begins at sunset on Friday and ends at sunrise on Saturday. For Muslims, their Sabbath begins at sunset on Friday night and ends at sunrise early Sunday morning. The area now called Galicia was first inhabited by humans during the Middle Paleolithic period, and it takes its name from the Gallaeci, the Germanic tribe that first inhabited the area. Their name is derived from the word gala, which means warrior or chivalrous man. The word gala is the same one used for Arthur in medieval legend. Galicia, Spanish for the plains of Gallaeci lands, would become an influential place on the Iberian Peninsula during this period. The area has a population of a little more than two million people today.

Birds have a very efficient system for diffusing oxygen into the blood; birds have a ten times greater surface area to gas exchange volume than mammals. Birds also have an extraordinarily efficient respiration at low to mid altitudes that keeps their heart rates and respiration rates very consistent and slow without a substantial increase in energy expenditure. It is possible birds might have evolved efficient systems for oxygenating the tissues that would have helped them in the early days of their evolutionary development. The lungs of birds contain an unusual set of respiratory structures called "bipodal" or "bony" spiracles, the first of its kind in any arthropod, and an abundance of respiratory muscle tissue that allows flight and the ability to quickly control one's gait. Y DNA studies tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths. In most Jewish populations, these founder events probably represent, at best, a very small subset of all the Jews. If they did represent a larger fraction (by 50%) of all the Jews, the most ancient Jewish ancestors likely began to appear about 10,000 years ago in Africa, with a substantial fraction of the Jewish gene pool coming from about 100,000 years ago (see Figure 1). This is somewhat less than the age of the first Jewish men from sub-Saharan Africa, so the evidence does not support the picture of a new migration from Africa to Europe and back. However, the new results add to the evidence for an ancient Jewish migration, and they help to eliminate the possibility that the most ancient Jews were a people who began their spread and admixture around the time of the Exodus (12,500 years ago).

Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid instead of ammonia.


Many vertebrates, such as salamanders, lagomorphs - a group of extinct mammals - have no uric acids. Instead their high uric acid content is taken up in a form similar to urea, used to produce urea which then converts to urochromes and urea-glucuronide. So a carnivore (or other obligate carnivore, since that usually relies on blood to survive) will always have a high concentration of urea-based proteins even if it has no uric acid.


In birds, the most common uric acid is chystrale, which is found in about 80 and 75 percent of the birds tested. The other uric acid is uric acid, which is made by birds at an even higher concentration.

In Homer's Iliad, the names Danaans (or Danaoi: Δαναοί) and Argives (Argives in Greek) are both generic terms for the Indo-European people of what will become the Balkans. In contrast to their western brethren, the Iranian peoples to whom the Greeks later attributed names such as Danaos and Homeros, the Danaan and the Argive peoples were Indo-Europeans who first appeared in the Aegean and Greek world ca. 2500 bc – ca. 2350 bc with settlements of this type spread from Athens to Sicily.

During the first great wave of the Indo-European expansion from ca. 1600 bc to 300 bc, the Danaans were part of this demographic wave. The Homeric epics (and their successors) in fact mention both the Danaans and the Argives. Many modern specialty matches have been devised, with unique winning conditions. The most common of these is the ladder match. In the basic ladder match, the player who makes it to the top of the ladder first wins. Some other formats of game play may also involve a ladder match, typically based on the order of draw of the players.

Some games also have a tiebreaker. Usually, a combination of tiebreakers are used, with players going back to the top of the ladder in the final and deciding game on how well they have done in the tiebreakers they have used, with the final one being the tiebreaker game.

Somewhere between the tiebreaker game and the main tournament is the "main event". During this tournament, various match formats may be used.

Sound could be stored in either analog or digital format and in a variety of surround sound formats; NTSC discs could carry two analog audio tracks, plus or minus one, while PAL-specification discs could carry three analog audio tracks, plus or minus two.

Sound was stored in the sound device. Audio signals were transmitted directly to the sound device and then encoded into a standard bit stream, which could then be decoded at the sound device. The signal could be stored on a magnetic disk or recorded on to a phonograph disc.

Because of the way these machines stored sound, some sources such as a tape may be better than others. For example, a phonograph may sound better than vinyl on some types of recordings. Also, a tape will retain more information than any other medium. For example, the sounds from many recordings might require many times more information than music available in a compact disc.

From his diagrams of a small number of particles interacting in spacetime, Feynman could then model all of physics in terms of the spins of those particles and calculate the motion of all the world's particles according to a complex mathematical formula. At first, Feynman never succeeded in the precise calculations he needed to prove his theorem to the satisfaction of his advisor, who found that they needed quite a lot of work. Then, in 1953, Feynman had an extraordinary realization: that he could solve this problem as completely as possible while in the midst of doing experiments—because of his mathematical ideas about interactions and field theory.

John's capture of Château Gaillard was widely reported in the English countryside. The English countryside was so consumed with war that the local media rarely reported news of any other topics (such as the death of John's sons and the burning of the castle). Château Gaillard was soon joined by its sister castle, Château de la Croix, to form a defensive network. In this paper, Richards et al. note that some groups that now seem to have a substantial number of African origins, have a very small Middle Eastern ancestry. Some groups, including many of the Ashkenazim, appear to have undergone a considerable number of admixture events with neighboring Arab tribes, but this should not result in a genetic bottleneck as a result of such long-distance admixture.

"The overall situation for the Ashkenazi appears to be much more complex than it was 20 years ago, and we find it hard to understand why this complex pattern started at a level it has gone to at present," Richards says. "This kind of complex pattern suggests some underlying processes may be at work for which we are yet to understand very well."

As a consequence of the success of its exhibitions, Cubiste was invited to a number of exhibitions around the world, often in its own exhibition "Le Cubiste". This was the first time that a European architect was allowed to go so far as to present his own architecture. It became widely known as the first true global gathering of modernism and art. The Montana Territory was formed on April 26, 1864, when the U.S. passed the Organic Act. Schools started forming in the area before 1870. In 1874, the territory was divided into three counties, Bannack, McDermitt, and Billings, to serve the schoolteachers. Today, schools in Helena and Billings provide a quality education to over 200 students, many of whom are refugees from other rural areas in Utah and Idaho.

Schools are not solely a matter of financial investment. They are also a way to improve cultural relations. "Every school that I have ever attended," said John Odey, a school teacher and member of the Western States Heritage Association, "has involved students in history and history's significance…it's important for the school to have a bond between the teacher and the students in that connection."

Jean Macfarlane founded the University of California, Berkeley's Institute of Human Development, formerly called the Institute of Child Welfare, in 1927. The Institute was designed to provide research, education and supervision to improve educational and child-rearing practices. Macfarlane was a pioneer of gender studies and a leading proponent of the feminist movement.

Over the decades, the Institute continued to evolve with Macfarlane's passing in 1976, and the Institute's faculty and affiliates became stronger. The Institute's most recent director, the feminist scholar Donna Haraway, received the 1993 American Psychological Association Award for distinguished service to psychology, as well as the 1993 American Psychological Association Women's Leadership Award.

Through its programs and fellowships, the Institute supports graduate students and undergraduate scholars in human development with opportunities for research, teaching and research training. The Institute also supports the graduate and professional schools, libraries and archives of the University of California, Berkeley.

Usually a Presbyterian church will not have statues of saints, nor the ornate altar more typical of a Roman Catholic church. Instead, one will find a table of wooden chairs, while next to stand a plain rectangular black altar, and a simple white cross.

In the early Christian church, the statues were often kept in cemeteries, so churches did not need to have such elaborate buildings. During the Renaissance, in fact, statues appeared mostly in churches, and some secular rulers like Frederick King of Prussia used them in their own churches. In Russia, the most recognizable Christian statues are Peter, Paul and Andrew, figures venerated as saints by several Russian Orthodox churches.

The main exception to this is China, where statues of the Christian saints and martyrs have been an integral part of Chinese architecture and art from the beginning of the sixteenth century. The Gupta princes (including Raja Man Singh), ruling from the capital city of Nandigram in Bihar, and the Gurjara princes (including Bhimsen Joshi), ruling in the southern states of Orissa and Uttar Pradesh, became known as the Nanda Dynasty. However, their first names are known only from the Nandigram documents and the Haryanavas documents, which may prove to be incomplete and inaccurate.

Though Britain and the empire emerged victorious from the Second World War, the effects of the conflict were profound, both at home and abroad. Much of Europe had been devastated by war and its post-war political and social upheavals. Yet the British remained deeply committed to empire, as did most of the European countries. Although Britain had never won a war on home soil, she had been at least as successful at projecting power. Britain's military and economic might provided the United States with a new base to project its imperial ambitions upon. In the decades leading up to the Second World War, Britain's military was transformed, primarily through the efforts of a handful of men at the Ministry of Munitions and of many others at the home front. However, the wartime experience, though traumatic, did not fundamentally alter the nature of the domestic British political landscape.

Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and complex. Memory is not static; it is continuously stored in our brain. The act of remembering, in the same way the act of making a record is, is an ongoing process of generating new, fresh memory and replaying it from one place to another in time-space so as to obtain a memory of something that occurred later. Memory, it should be emphasized, differs from ordinary memory, which is just remembering what you have been told, in the sense that'memory' refers to memories which represent actual events which occurred to the person at the time and which have not been forgotten by him, in the sense of being remembered only in part.

A common way in which emotions are conceptualized in sociology is in terms of the multidimensional characteristics including cultural or emotional labels (e.g., emotional violence), individual characteristics (e.g., depression), and interpersonal patterns (e.g., interpersonal problems), in which the first two dimensions represent individual behavioral constructs and the interpersonal pattern dimensions are seen as defining personal behavior. In a similar vein, the emotions and disorders theory proposes that there are emotions and disorders which result from the complex interconnections among the three dimensions of emotions described thus far. Although not necessarily exclusive, there is growing evidence in the literature to suggest that, in some cases, only one of the dimensions of emotions is considered important within the field.

This interdependence of individual behavioral constructs that can coactivate or interact with each other has been found to hold true for mood disorders, anxiety disorders, and substance use disorders. It was the first letter they had ever received from each other. This letter revealed an extraordinary relationship between Darwin and Wallace. In one letter Wallace mentions the possibility of spontaneous mutation.

The natural selection theory proposed by Darwin was based on both "junk" and "workable" concepts, i.e., "junk" meaning "not biologically significant or useful, i.e., non-functional but useful," whereas "workable" means "useful."

The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only. A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend the bylaws—that is, to change its bylaws.

A board-only organization is a special type of nonprofit organization the bylaws are made by the board rather than elected and is controlled by officers, often the organization's president. The officers are entitled to veto changes to the bylaws and to provide the board with nonvoting financial assistance. The board of directors can adopt bylaws that override and supersede the bylaws of the membership organization.

For example, suppose that an association maintains a membership organization and a board-only organization. In the past, the membership organization gave a vote to each person who paid membership dues. In the past, the board-only organization elected all officers and approved the bylaws. Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. A single sample will grow for a period of time that may vary from several days, months or even years to weeks or months, depending on the species of the agent and the growth conditions. Because of the rapidity with which infections are spread in the medical world, most cultures contain a wide range of agents. Because bacteria and viruses can be cultured in a wide variety of growth conditions, including low concentration media, medium that is sterile and medium that is supplemented with growth aids, they can be placed in a variety of settings to mimic the types of settings in which they might exist.

Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much influence on the family or society as a whole. Some children exhibit greater maturity in their behavior during this period, sometimes displaying a more assertive nature and sometimes growing weary of household chores, socializing, or other duties that are expected of them.

Children enter maturity between the ages of 10 and 15. They develop and increase in physical strength and begin to develop social maturity. During this time the child must learn life lessons that provide them with the tools for self-fulfillment. These lessons are best learned through observation of other children and their parents, and by playing the role that is given to the child.

The European concept of "race", along with many of the ideas now associated with the term, arose at the time of the scientific revolution, which introduced the notion of natural selection - the idea that traits are inherited by descent. As with many cultural theories, the theory was later discredited, particularly in the 20th century, when evolutionary theory replaced it.

However, many modern-day Americans think of race as hereditary, with specific genetic differences between different races. People have been fascinated by claims that whites have evolved white skin through the process of selective breeding, while East Asians often have dark skin due to the fact that they had darker skin in their original homeland. Recent research has also shown that our DNA could be viewed as a mixture of European and African DNA, with many areas of the genome potentially influenced by both.

The initial military maneuvers began in September 1806. In a notable letter to Marshal Soult detailing the plan for the campaign, Napoleon described the essential features of his strategy: (1) to capture St. Jean de Luz; (2) to capture the town of St. Eustache; (3) to take the road to Lyon and capture Le Mans; (4) to take the road to Bordeaux and capture Le Mans; (5) to capture Bordeaux and Marseilles, where he planned to set up a central government in the form of a republic; (6) to capture the strategic port of Antwerp and divert the French fleet stationed there; (7) to capture the strategic port of Mons and divert the French naval fleet stationed there; and (8) to move forward from St. Eustache on a north-south line with its port at Le Mans to capture Antwerp. Jefferson refused to issue Proclamations of Thanksgiving sent to him by Congress during both his first and second terms. Jefferson expressed his belief that such communications violate the fundamental principles of democracy and democracy's inherent right to free speech. He asserted that, if Congress sent a message of Thanksgiving "to the People … from the Government, or a Citizen… as a part of it." Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a particular view of the world, where they see the world through the narrow lens of one's own particular beliefs or ideals. A person who maintains an inclusive boundary on the other side of which one cannot be included, thus, cannot be excluded from that perspective. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person's own viewpoints are viewed by another as unacceptable and incompatible with those of the non-believer. The person who maintains an exclusive boundary on the other side of which one cannot be included, thus, would be excluded from the person's viewpoint.

The relationships adolescents have with their peers, family, and members of their social sphere play a vital role in the social development of an adolescent. As an example, a new study published in the journal PLoS ONE provides important insight into the brain changes in adolescent siblings who are abused.

Researchers from the University of Toronto, the University of Waterloo and other centers in Canada have found an additional brain structure in abused siblings that they did not see in the other siblings they scanned.

The findings, which have been published in the January issue of Child Development, show that a portion of a part of the cerebellum, called the dentate gyrus, which controls motor skills, is larger in adolescent siblings who have suffered repeated physical and emotional abuse.

This is the first study to assess the effects of sexual abuse of siblings and the first to link these observed differences to differences in the dentate gyrus in the brains of these adolescents.

Most fatty acids are non-essential, meaning the body can produce them as needed, generally from other fatty acids and always by expending energy to do so.

The best sources of fatty acids are animal fat and high-fat plant foods like coconut oil and flax seeds.

Fatty acids have special structures, known as fatty acid chains, in their chemical structures that can be attached to molecules of fat or other substances, such as sugars, protein, and vitamins. Thus, the essential fatty acid is actually a chain of non-essential fatty acids, made up of chains of alternating fatty acid chains.

Essential fatty acids are considered to be nutrients essential to a healthy body and mind, whereas non-essential fatty acids can be included in any of the normal food groups in a diet. In the wake of the Coventry Blitz, there was widespread agitation from the Communist Party over the need for bomb-proof shelters. Many Londoners, living in unassuming tenements with little protection, sought their own escape routes. They built underground shelters at the base of apartment buildings, or in their garages, often as temporary measures during the Blitz, only to have them quickly stripped by the authorities during the bombing. By the end of the war, they had taken more than 300,000 lives during the Blitz—more than all German combat deaths.[1]

Following the Sergeant Isaac Woodard incident, President Harry S. Truman, himself a combat veteran of World War I, issued Executive Order 9808 establishing the Armed Forces Radio Broadcast Service in June 1942.

Truman's order required all military members to establish and maintain radio stations, to receive regular transmissions from Army units operating in various theaters of operation, to transmit such transmissions, and, of course, to transmit them, not only as a military broadcast but also for their general dissemination through civilian stations and wire services. By issuing his orders, Truman committed the U.S. Army to the radio project.

Despite the war efforts, the radio broadcast service proved to be less efficient than the wire service. This was due to a number of factors, including Army officials' insistence that Army units be authorized to transmit over the radio, without having to first obtain approval from the State Governors. The service also faced logistical difficulties--radio transmission equipment was of poor quality and many stations experienced technical difficulties.

A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each, known as halves. Each half runs continuously, meaning that the clock is not stopped or reset and so no stoppage occurs unless a substitution needs to be made.

The game lasts 2 hours 15 minutes. There are no half-time breaks nor do goal-line technology kicks in between halves.

The rules state that no "play is stopped or interrupted by an on-field action unless the stoppage results from direct fouls or misconduct." Therefore, even if a stoppage results from violent action, any referee would know before the game that it has a negative effect on the game and would not call it. This would obviously not be the purpose of "Rule 34", which says: "No further stoppage is permitted in such way as to endanger the normal flow of the game."

Communication within peer groups allows adolescents to explore their feelings and identity as well as develop and evaluate their social skills. Peer groups offer members the opportunity to identify with others and develop relationships with peer groups of like-minded people. Peer groups, then, can reinforce the peer group system in which individuals learn more and more skills from their peers through interactions at these social contacts, and as more they come to possess more skills, they progress through the peer group system to increasingly higher social status and influence within the peer group system. If the social skills of the group are weak, the group will not develop enough power to move them into leadership positions within the group.

Social competence as a function of peer group membership includes an understanding how to relate not only to your peers as well as to your supervisor, but also to your bosses, as well as to other organizations. In 1681, in partial repayment of a debt, Charles II of England granted William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony. Despite the loss of the Great Charter following a series of rebellions, Penn continued to seek new tracts of land. With the help of Pennsylvania legislators, like the Honorable Nathaniel Bradford, he acquired two tracts near Plymouth and another near Philadelphia.

The Treaty of London on April 29, 1691 placed responsibility for paying the debts of the Dutch colony with the French colony. The payment was intended to satisfy the colonists who had protested against payment. After a series of violent raids, in 1692 Penn agreed to cede to the settlers in his lands four of the eight parcels that had been ceded by his predecessor.

In 1693 Penn signed the Treaty of Paris. The next year, Penn's father, Sir John Penn, was born in Holland. The Penns came to North America later that year, sailing from England with the first colonists.

The empire rose to prominence as an economic power in the Japanese colonies during the Tokugawa Shogunate and eventually led to its merger with the Shoguns after the death of the first Tokugawa in 1600.

Under the Emperor Hidetsugu I we saw a significant reduction in population with many people fleeing to various parts of China but overall the Empire had been maintained and even improved by the Tokugawa as they expanded their domains from the northern part of Japan to as far as Korea. Even after the Shōgun became the emperor of China in 1614, the Tokugawa continued to rule Japan until 1854 when the last Tokugawa Shōgun, Otsu Tokimune, fled China back to Japan and his heir, the future Tokugawa Shogun, Tokugawa Ieyasu, was established.

Chapter XI deals with evidence from biogeography, starting with the observation that differences in flora and fauna from separate regions cannot be explained by environmental differences. Instead, the study of geography shows that, like a fingerprint, the flora and fauna of a region can be predicted for a range of environmental conditions due to the effect of topography and the climate on plant and animal populations. For example, in the New World tropics, most mammal species live in dense forests, with few plants and a low biodiversity. Many areas in North America have similar topographical conditions, but tropical rodents are found nowhere, while carnivores are found throughout the American south.

Cultural influences also alter ecosystems. As the study of the ecology of the human environment has grown, so have new environmental pressures and conflicts. Hiberni (Ireland), Pictish (northern Britain) and Britons (southern Britain) tribes, all speaking Insular Celtic, inhabited the British Isles and were closely connected by trade and culture.

The original Celtic languages have been forgotten or lost to history; Celtic languages and dialects were spoken from the 6th century BC onward, mainly in Britain.[63] According to most scholars, the Celts of Scotland and Ireland are descended from the peoples called Cymry, Celtic tribes or Britons.[64] These peoples were known as Picts by Romans, Britons by the British people, and so on. Most scholars agree that Picts had three classes of citizenship of which the upper class were the nobility and the lower were the people. Cymry were not subject to an aristocracy and were ruled by a priestly class called the priesthood. Some authorities suggest that the word "Celts" comes from the Greek word "ελλῷτρος"

The vast Seleucid Empire was, like Egypt, mostly dominated by a Greco-Macedonian political elite. The Greek population of the Seleucid Empire was in decline, and was in constant flux, having experienced periodic periods of depopulation. As a consequence of this, the ancient Greeks were, like the Egyptian and Seleucid Greeks, highly mobile, able to move anywhere on the basis of a mobile economy. This also meant that once they took a region of central Palestine, they were largely indifferent to the religious or ethnic affiliation of the surrounding population. From the point of view of the Seleucid rulers, they were not concerned with the identities of their subjects; rather they were concerned with the wealth and power that was contained within the land. The ancient and modern Jewish people have a similar situation to ancient and modern Greeks: The ancient Jewish people are mostly not interested in the identities of their religious and ethnic neighbors. Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding plumage".

The feathers on the head and flanks, the talons and the beak (gizzard) are all considered part of the pre-breeding plumage and so must be removed, and sometimes a part of a bird that has moulted must be preserved to protect itself from predation.

It is thought that after breeding the sexes develop different plumage, because in early development, all other parts of the bird are covered with the same feather cells.

However, not all parts of the plumage are equally important in survival. The beak is thought to be one of the most important parts in pre-breeding plumage because of the importance of a beak to feeding, and to helping a bird keep a balance in balance between itself and the environment.

As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of these are created outside of cells due to the action of UV radiation as a direct byproduct of DNA replication. Other free radicals, which are the cause of disease, are formed in cell walls, macromolecules, and in specialized parts of cells called mitochondria. Mitochondria contain the cells' DNA, and therefore have a special role in metabolism (see the page about Energy Production, Energy Supplies and Energy Metabolism for more information).

Despite Martin Luther's harsh polemics against his Roman Catholic opponents over issues concerning Mary and the saints, theologians appear to agree that Luther adhered to a similar perspective in his comments against the Catholic Church and the saints. This is a common claim about the Reformation: "But you know, Luther, that you always say the same thing!" Unfortunately, this kind of comparison is difficult to prove when it comes to Luther's writings. Some theologians claim that Luther's commentaries often include a list of supposed "allusions" in which he mentions "saints" and "bishops," but there is no evidence that the Church Fathers were even aware of these references. In fact, some Church Fathers seem to make it very clear that they had no idea about Martin Luther's claims. In 1905, Lord Curzon split the large province of Bengal into a largely Hindu western half and "Eastern Bengal and Assam", a largely Muslim eastern half. Curzon's decision angered both Hindus and Muslims in Bengal. His successor, Lord Macaulay, appointed an all-Muslim Council to negotiate with British politicians over Bengal's future. Their offer was to give equal rights to Hindus and Muslims within the existing British Indian empire, but for Curzon to get the Indians to accept this would require the British to give up control of India, which was seen as a threat to the interests of both the United Kingdom and Curzon himself.

Curzon was opposed by the most senior British official in Bengal, Prime Minister David Lloyd George (no relation to the famous Victorian archaeologist). The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical reality had very different implications from statements about mental objects. Physical states are no longer simply mental objects on which to pin our attention, but are rather something much deeper to be looked at in terms of what it means for a set of statements to be true or false. For instance, statements about the motion of a ship cannot be regarded as true or false because motion does not occur at all in the mind and no laws or relationships exist to connect a thought about motion with the actual motion of the ship itself.

Despite the growing appreciation of the fundamental difference between physical and mental states of affairs, the phenomenalist, despite being generally a naturalist, felt a sort of hesitance to drop his metaphysics in response to physicalism. Non-religious Umayyad mosaic works were mainly floor panels which decorated the palaces of the caliphs and other high-ranking officials. Although the Islamic religious landscape became far removed from its pagan foundations following the Abbasid Revolution of the early 13th century, the Islamic pattern for architecture was still in place.


The main Islamic design was the so-called qanati, that is, an array of rectilinear, straight-faced pillars that stood above the floor. This was followed by the tiling of the roof which began with rectilinear pillars and arches. After these initial features were covered by a mosaic, the ceiling would be covered by mosaics with floral and geometric motifs. By August 1805, Napoleon had realized that the strategic situation had changed fundamentally. Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies, he decided to strike out from his French territories and drive the British out of the islands. His goal was to gain control of the islands and prevent the spread of the French Revolution by reducing or destroying their British protector. However, the French Army was spread too thin and was completely unprepared to win the land war; they simply retreated back to France. Napoleon went back to Europe to plan where to go next, and as his invasion time grew close, he received news of the British plan that Napoleon's main army was too spread out to effectively attack. He knew how he had failed in France and that he had no better option now; he made the decision to withdraw, and in August 1805, he sailed from France for the final time. In a climate of global warming at 1 degree above the preindustrial level, the City of Melbourne plans to reduce emissions by 70 per cent to 55 per cent of 2000 levels by 2050.

This will require substantial cuts in greenhouse gas emissions from the electricity and gas industries combined with an extensive program of large-scale renewable energy generation. The City estimates it must eliminate 6300 MW in electricity generation by 2020 and almost 2200 MW by 2050 to meet these targets. This is a substantial amount of power that in some cases will cost Australians some of the highest power prices in the world

Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It has a history of use that is at least 10,000 years old, and its use in jewellery has been documented from 5000 BC. Its use in jewelry has continued into the present-day.

The most interesting thing about copper is the amount of copper it contains, and the fact that it is a metal with a fairly high melting point. Copper is a metal with an extremely large amount of energy stored in it, and the heat produced during the melting process can be used to create electricity. One of the reasons why the Romans used copper rather than iron for their weapons was the fact that copper held a higher thermal conductivity compared to iron. A high heat transfer coefficient allowed more heat to be carried away in one direction, making the metal the ideal choice for weapons.

The islands are at relatively low altitudes, with central Ireland and southern Great Britain particularly low lying: the lowest point in the islands is Holme, or around 80m below sea level and the highest point in Ireland, Ballyshannon, is around 350m above sea level. In contrast, the highest point in British Guiana, which is very flat over most of their range (notably on the east coast) is around 500m above sea level. The high point in Anguilla is just over 700m above sea level but is reached only in summer.

The islands are isolated from the mainland so a strong breeze or strong, northerly winds will carry the heat and humidity up from the cooler waters off the coast to much higher areas of high pressure. Different phases of digestion take place including: the cephalic phase, gastric phase, and intestinal phase. The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s. Species are increasingly being moved by humans (on farms, on islands and even through the mail), so this is not just a concern for the species themselves, but for species that we depend on for food, such as some bird species. They may not always do well in new habitats, and they can also encounter human health hazards, such as antibiotic-resistant diseases. The increase in number of invasions is a cause for concern not only for those that are impacted by these organisms, but also for a wide range of organisms that use the same water for their survival.

Why are we seeing such big numbers of species invasions across all types of habitats? The situation varies on a species level, with some species going through a burst of new invaders and others recovering from decades of sustained low numbers. The first significant work that expressed scientific theory and knowledge expressly for the laity, in the vernacular, and with the entertainment of readers in mind, was La Sagesse Aventurier, a four volume work in six volumes by an obscure monk and scientist in the order of Benedictines. In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the huge advances made throughout the century, the technology remained somewhat inefficient. The phonautographer was expensive, prone to malfunction and would require manual adjustments due to the poor quality of microphones and speaker combinations.

In 1927, J. P. Morgan and J. W. Carnegie had the idea to combine Edison's invention with other new technologies to create the first commercial computer. To create a sound recording of the same length as a human voice, a two-inch tape was mounted with a microphone to record audio with the voice. Using a reel-to-reel player, players would play a record using an electromagnet, which would rotate the tape along with the needle, resulting in recording sound. At this level of performance, the record could be sent across the radio frequency transmission spectrum by radio receivers, effectively creating a computer.

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and reproduction; it is involved in the regulation and elimination of toxins; it is responsible for the production and destruction of cell structures, including the cell nucleus [9]. Energy is a major determinant (pigment and enzyme, especially) of physical, chemical and biological processes. It represents the sum of all work done within the cell. Energy does not exist in empty space, as energy is required in the development of any biological substance [10]. It is the sum of all work performed within the cell.

The cellular organization of human beings involves the use of energy, because this organization requires the efficient and precise allocation of energy by the cell. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid, all owed their birth, first and foremost, to Virgil, who is known to have been the best-read writer in that field of scholarship. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajtak, Miskolian, Old Church Slavonic and Modern Bulgarian) have been spoken side by side with modern Bulgarian, and in some instances the vernacular, or traditional, tongue was used over the language of the region (e.g. Eastern Slavo-Slovene / Western Slavo-Slovene). But the transition from literary writing to the written language was not yet complete; the majority of people in this region still spoke literary Cyrillic for a few years, even if not necessarily on a daily basis. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury, Gemini and Apollo. The U.S. placed its first two astronauts on the Space Station in 1976 and 1978, followed in 1979 by its third. The Soviet Union's first two space capsules were launched in 1965. It took the Soviets five years to fly one into orbit. NASA also launched its first astronaut into space when its astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first Americans to orbit Earth in 1969. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the island is covered in basaltic volcanoes). The island lies in some of the most extreme weather regimes on Earth. For example, the island experiences average winter temperature of -58.2° Celsius, which is 0.5° Celsius warmer than the global average of -40.9° and -42.1° Celsius respectively.


In terms of surface area it is smaller than that of the continental United States. On average, over the last 25 years around 6,100 residents have emigrated each year from the island.

Geographically, the island of Saint Helena is characterized by thick volcanic tectonic plate boundaries. The volcanic surface is composed mainly of basaltic lava. This lava was formed on and after the last major volcanic eruption within the last 5000 years. There are also several large volcanic craters. These features

In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12 hours of footage each night. This was called the "Midnight Special."

In a way, it's the classic recording for its time. Though Gabler uses a more technical approach than many sound men of the time, he still makes interesting use of the microphones and his own vocal stylings to create a story and, most importantly, capture the essence of the events taking place. There is a great deal of tension and mystery built into each recording. Here, he is in a small cottage; a very dangerous place to be at night. One minute he's out front; the next, up inside his own home. There's lots of very tense moments of negotiation, some shouting and much shouting. Most memorable is a shot of a woman screaming; an event that is of great importance to the characters in Gabler's stories.

"Its effects may be beneficial, but these have to be carefully assessed. The introduction of these animals should be banned and the animals should be destroyed."

Genetic engineers have modified plants, animals, insects, fungal spores, bacteria and micro-organisms for medical, research or agricultural uses. They are used in laboratories, in the food industry, and in pest controllers.

This philosophical belief was based on the idea that science and faith can't be reconciled.

Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: The Ticino Plateau which occupies parts of the lower half of the country, the Valsetzes Mountains to the east and north-west, and the Alps to the south-west. The Valsetzes and Ticino have a high mountainous surface, consisting of a mixture of limestone and glacial deposits, that has been shaped by glacial movement since the last Ice Age about 15 million years ago. It has a long coastline. The country is bordered by the Swiss Confederation, along with Liechtenstein, Canada and the United States. There are 17 different nationalities found inside Switzerland, most of which are not associated with specific ethnic groups.

In December, Beyoncé along with a variety of other celebrities teamed up and produced a video campaign for "Demand A Plan", a bipartisan effort by a large group of lawmakers to reduce the costs of health care.

On Tuesday, Beyoncé announced she was donating $500k to Planned Parenthood for the rest of her life.

Beyoncé announced the gift was in memory of her mother, Gloria Carter, who died in 2002 at the age of 79 and was diagnosed with ALS after a long battle with the disease.

As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that clerics should focus exclusively on their religious duties carried much more weight - and with it, the legitimacy of the waqf system. From the 12th through the 14th centuries Islamic scholars developed this conception and its logical opposite, "sharif." Sharif also involved the acceptance of the jurisprudence of the caliph, and the establishment of institutions under the shari'a law. As we shall see below, only a small minority of Sunni theologians in the early 19th century called Shariah shari'a. The majority of those clerics (most of whom, like Muhammad Husayn ibn Munabbih, belonged to the Mu'tazilite stream of jurisprudence) argued that any government that established the authority of clerics over the public sphere would have violated the sacred law of shari'a.
